name: Thorin Oakenshield
description: Thorin Oakenshield is the leader of the company of dwarves seeking to reclaim Erebor and its treasure from the dragon Smaug.

content.title: Background
content.body: Thorin II Oakenshield is a proud and noble dwarf prince, the rightful heir to the Kingdom under the Mountain, Erebor. Son of Thráin II and grandson of Thrór, Thorin carries the heavy legacy of his ancestors after their kingdom was lost to Smaug, the dragon. Known for his distinctive nickname 'Oakenshield' earned during the Battle of Azanulbizar where he used a broken oak branch as a shield, Thorin is a central figure in The Hobbit, organizing and leading the quest to reclaim Erebor. His lineage ties him deeply to the wealth and history of the Lonely Mountain.

content.title: Personality
content.body: Thorin is characterized by his steadfast determination, deep sense of honor, and pride in his heritage. He possesses a regal dignity and commands respect from his followers, yet his noble traits are shadowed by bouts of stubbornness and occasional arrogance. His overwhelming desire to regain his kingdom and treasure sometimes blinds him to reason, leading to strained relations with his companions. Despite these flaws, Thorin's courage and leadership inspire loyalty, and ultimately, his actions are motivated by a yearning to restore the glory of the dwarves.

content.title: Story Role
content.body: As the leader of the questing company, Thorin is the driving force behind the mission to reclaim the Lonely Mountain. His leadership is pivotal in navigating dangers from goblins, wolves, elves, and Smaug himself. Throughout the novel, his character arc explores themes of courage, sacrifice, and the corrupting influence of greed. His tragic end during the Battle of Five Armies marks a significant turning point, underscoring the cost of his obsession with the treasure. Thorin's legacy deeply influences the fate of Erebor and the wider world of Middle-earth.

content.title: Relationships
content.body: Thorin shares a complex relationship with most members of his company, including a strong paternal bond with his kin such as Fili and Kili, whom he deeply cares for. His rapport with Bilbo Baggins evolves from skepticism to grudging respect as Bilbo proves his worth. Thorin’s ties with other characters, such as the Elvenking and Bard the Bowman, are marked by tension and conflict, particularly over territorial and treasure disputes. Additionally, his relationship with Gandalf is cooperative but sometimes strained due to differing priorities.

content.title: Abilities and Skills
content.body: Thorin is skilled in combat, strategy, and leadership, reflecting his royal upbringing and experience in battle. He wields the sword Orcrist, famed for its effectiveness against goblins. His combat prowess is notable in several encounters, including the Battle of Azanulbizar and the Battle of Five Armies. Beyond martial ability, Thorin exhibits keen judgment in navigating political and interpersonal challenges, albeit tempered by his occasional pride. His leadership qualities are inspiring to his fellow dwarves, driving their loyalty and determination.
